title: Tuesday, 3rd November, 2015
bodyHTML:

PM

PM

PM

And there's quite a lot to get thru this morning

But first

PM

I meant to highlight this on Friday

PM

But forgot

11:03 am
BE

First, to deal with @squarepeg's question: dunno.

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 224.90, up 24.6 (+12.28%), High: 225.54, Low: 199.50, Volume: 4.53m
BE

Live price up nearly 15%

11:04 am
BE

No-one seems to have heard a specific rumour, or if anyone was they haven't told me.

BE

Volume's decent though.

BE

There's a Nomura note out on Tullow but I seriously doubt that's the catalyst.

11:05 am
BE

Let me share anyway.

PM

hmm

BE

Progress on key issues has been mixed into next week’s trading update (11 November). 1) Execution at TEN is proceeding according to plan, with sail-away of the floating production storage and offloading (FPSO) expected around year-end. 2) Debt facilities remain intact following a successful redetermination process for the RBL. 3) The development of resources in East Africa has become more uncertain with Uganda undecided on a pipeline route through Kenya or Tanzania. We view a Tanzania pipeline as less likely, but if chosen we estimate that the negative impact on the commerciality of TLW’s Kenya assets (currently 50p/sh risked) would more than offset any improvement to Uganda’s (45p/sh). Meanwhile, this halts progress and further weakens the likelihood of an asset deal in East Africa pending a decision in 1Q16. Moreover, 95p of our 193p base case NAV is attributable to East Africa. We therefore reiterate our cautious view.

11:06 am
BE

Tanzania pipeline unlikely to be as low cost as Kenyan option…
Uganda has reopened discussions with Tanzania over a possible pipeline route that would effectively bypass Tullow’s resources in Kenya. We understand that the key reason for this is to maximise the commerciality of its oil through the lowest possible tariff, but we struggle to see how a Tanzanian pipeline could compete with a Kenyan one given shared resources and costs.

BE

… But an independent Kenya project would affect commerciality
Without significant new resource discoveries in the Kenyan rift valley, an independent Kenyan oil pipeline could result in a 50% increase in tariff costs (USD 8-10/bbl), assuming a capex estimate of cUSD 2bn (50% of original concept) and a more front-loaded production profile, albeit following a delayed start. This would reduce the Kenya upstream internal rate of return (IRR) (from 2016) to c15% from 18% currently and reduce our risked NAV by 14p.

BE

November 11th trading update preview – Focus on TEN and asset sales
TEN: First oil expected mid-2016. Asset sales: Management has discussed the possibility of asset sales as a means to protect the balance sheet. Jubilee FFD: A full-field development concept should be submitted to government by year end. 2015 Production guidance: 66-70 kboe/d from West Africa, and 6-8 kboe/d from Europe. 2015 Capex: USD 1.9bn including USD 250m of expl.

11:06 am
BE

We've done the Tullow takeover theory a hundred times ......

BE

It's in a rather tough spot for funding TEN, needing either perfect execution or more cash.

BE

And on that basis it doesn't look particularly cheap.

11:07 am
PM

It had a huge rally a month go

PM

And Tullow is always volatile, no?

PM

11:08 am
BE

Yup. It's hugely geared to the oil price curve, and is funding current capex needs with debt.

BE

As well as selling assets. Anyway, if we get something firmer we'll come back to it.

undefined
11:09 am
PM

Standard chartered

PM

Come on

PM

How valuable has our advice been on this thing

11:10 am
PM

Seriously

PM

Entire sell side was drawn into this prematurely

PM

Well, maybe not entire sell side

let me get the cahrt

Brilliant -- adn blindingly obvious

Not sure exactly when we first issed our "avoid" advice (later updated to "wait")

BE

What everyone seems to be forgetting is that this is Stan's third rights issue in seven years. £1.8bn in 2008, £3.3bn in 2010 and £3.3bn again today.

11:11 am
BE

It's a money pit.

PM

And will this even be enough?

PM

I seem to remember when Winters was appointed we thought the bank needed closer to £10bn

11:12 am
BE

Nope. But, like Glencore, it has a difficult shareholder list. So, like Glencore, it held off the fundraising far too long and went too small when it had to pull the trigger.

BE

The rule with rights issues is that you go big and go early.

BE

STAN's done neither.

11:13 am
BE

Repeatedly, in fact. It's failed to go big and early three times in a decade.

BE

Worth highlighting also that the results are amazingly bad.

PM

hehehe

11:13 am
BE

As in horrendous. Clear deteriorating trends.

BE

Do we have any confidence yet that impairments have been reset to foundation levels.

PM

I dont see how you can

11:14 am
BE

Do we have any confidence that the right 15,000 staff will be punted?

BE

It's now a lossmaking bank with no visibility on EM bad debts and whose capital is too thin ahead of a stress test.

PM

Ha -- well that kinda sums it up!

11:15 am
BE

In the circumstances, £3.3bn barely even touches the sides.

PM

To be fair to sell side people Joseph Dickerson at Jefferies was a seller

PM

Poor underlying performance is the real story today despite strategic review which results in a $5.1bn rights issue. The issue will fund $3bn of restructuring charges to take out a net $2bn of costs (17% of the '14 base) through 2018 and a targeted $25bn of RWA reduction. We remain UNDERPERFORM on STAN.

Impairments the big surprise. We have been running a Street high estimate for impairments and the 3Q15 impairment charge of $1.23bn is well above the run rate implied by our 2H15E charge of $1.65bn. Pressure remains India and Commodities.

Revenue down 18% in Q3 driven by a decline in client activity and de-risking. Not one business segment delivered positive YoY revenue growth. Trade finance down 19% YoY, Fin Mkt down 29% YoY and Wealth Mgt, previously a succor, down 9% YoY and 19% QoQ.

11:16 am
PM

Expenses down 3% YoY with operating expenses down 4% and regulatory costs up 44% YoY. Management now plans to take out $2bn of net costs, or 17% of the base (this figure includes the $600m originally guided for 2015, for a net $1.3bn reduction over 2016-18E).

Loans down 9% YoY, driven by de-risking in China (-15% YTD) and Commodities (-21% YTD) and risk management. QoQ, loans were down 5pct and RWAs down 4%, so RWAs falling less than loans. Group is targeting a net $25bn in RWA reductions (8% of current RWA base) and a repositioning of $75bn of RWAs into more efficient businesses.

Capital 10bps backwards to 11.4% and group likely to take a CVA charge in Q4 (unquantified). New capital target range of 12-13% and $5.1bn rights issue (we had estimated $8bn, so the level looks light and likely to place substantial constraints on the go forward business) announced today with rights issued at a 35% discount to yesterday's close and a 29% discount to the TERP. On end 1H15 results,, this raises the CET1 by 160bps. Further, the final dividend for 2015 has been eliminated.

PM

We remain at Underperform for the following reasons: 1) the underlying business trends are poor; 2) the capital raise and restructuring are fraught with execution risks; 3) the group CEO and CFO have no experience in such an undertaking; 4) US conduct fines that could cost from zero to several billion USD; 5) STAN does not yet know its result in the forthcoming UK bank stress test (1 Dec); 6) the bank has not raised enough capital in our view - today's capital raise is the exact amount raised in 2010 - it was not enough then and is unlikely to be now.

PM

he's with you Bryce!

11:17 am
PM

And me for that matter

BE

It's a very good point that Winters hasn't done this before.

PM

it's a wreck

11:17 am
BE

There's a big difference between running JPMorgan and trying to fix this thing.

BE

Ian Gordon also cautious.

PM

He's cautious now

11:19 am
BE

Today’s Q3 IMS reports an awful $139m underlying loss for Q3 2015 (vs consensus estimates of a £903m profit), and is accompanied by the launch of a 2-for-7 £3.3bn rights issue. The 2015 final dividend is also cancelled. There will be an analyst meeting at 9:30am. As we feared, the worst aspect of the result is a broad-based collapse in revenues, down 18% YoY to $3.7bn, but this is also accompanied by broadly flat costs ($2.5bn) and a further rise in impairments to $1.4bn (+10% QoQ, +158% YoY), hence the grim reality.

Although consensus estimates have been falling rapidly ahead of today’s Q3 IMS, our current full-year EPS forecasts of 64.5c in 2015e, 56.4c in 2016e and 96.5c in 2017e remain 20%, 34% and 24% below Bloomberg consensus. Our own forecasts are under review, and we expect consensus to “rebase” sharply lower once the detail of today’s Strategic Review has been absorbed.

Q3 2015 revenues of $3.7bn were down 10% QoQ, and down 18% YoY. The collapse is broad-based including YoY reductions in Trade (-19%), Financial Markets (-28%), Corporate Finance (-13%) and Personal Unsecured (-29%).

Costs of $2.5bn were down just 1% YoY, and included increased levels of regulatory expenses ($237m) and restructuring costs ($25m).

The Impairment charge increased to $1.4bn (+10% QoQ, +158% YoY). This primarily reflected continued elevated impairments in India and Commodities, as well as writedowns against certain strategic investments ($0.2bn). Coverage of non-performing loans has been raised from 54% to 58%.

The CET1 capital ratio declined by only 0.1% QoQ to 11.4%, but in conjunction with a far-reaching strategic review, STAN has announced a £3.3bn rights issue, with no 2015 final dividend. It now targets a CET1 ratio of 12-13% after restructuring greater than $100bn RWAs (one third of group), and it targets $2.9bn of cost reductions, with c.15,000 job cuts and $3bn of restructuring charges.

BE

Hang on, I'll try to find someone who's a buyer down here.

BE

There must be someone.

11:22 am

A lot to chew today morning. Capital is higher than we thought –earnings is weaker but then there is definitely a strong tilt to derisking before the raise. We will get back to you with more around our views post the strategy details

PM

BE

He's a good analyst, but like a lot of Bernstein people it could be argued that his skill is identifying woods rather than trees.

11:23 am
BE

How about Goldman?

BE

Based on a first take, we see the announcements as mixed as (1) the cap
hike quantum is broadly in-line with recent press coverage (Bloomberg,
October 30); (2) The RWA measures are complex and (i) do not foresee any
major business exits (or participation disposals) and (ii) the precise extent
to which today’s measures encompass previously announced actions at
this stage remains unclear. Based on a first take, around $25bn appears to
be incremental ($20bn of higher risk asset reduction and $5bn of peripheral
business exits). (3) On costs, the new strategy foresees an incremental
gross cost reduction of $1.1bn (c.10%), driven by a reduction of branches
by 10% and head count by 15,000. Finally, the ROE target of c.8% by 2018,
on our estimates, implies PBT of c. $6.4bn and compares to 2017 companycompiled
consensus estimates of $5.1bn.

BE

INVESTMENT LIST MEMBERSHIP
Pan-Europe Buy List

11:29 am
BE

JUST EAT (OW) has increased its like-for-like order growth rate in Q3 15
(+48% YoY) compared to H1 15 (+47%), which we think is impressive given
the rapidly increasing base effect. We had looked for +36% LFL growth, i.e.
the company beat by +12ppts. The UK grew +50% YoY in Q3, better than H1
(+49%). We believe weather may have added a few ppts to growth; even so, it
reinforces our view that delivery networks like Deliveroo can operate in their
niche focused on upscale restaurants, while at the same time JE can continue
to deliver strong growth across the mass market for takeaway food delivery.
The company has upped its 15E revenue guidance, and we increase group
revenues by +4%/+4% in 15E/16E and Underlying EBITDA (assuming some
reinvestment) by +2%/+2%. Our Dec-16E Price Target increases from 630p to
650p, and JE remains our top pick in Online. On our estimates, it trades on
30x/20x 16/17E EV/EBITDA with +49% 15E-18E EBITDA CAGR.

BE

"30x/20x 16/17E EV/EBITDA with +49% 15E-18E EBITDA CAGR"

BE

Aye, okay, whatever.

11:30 am
BE

 Q3 group order volumes grew +64%/+48% on a reported/LFL basis,
including +50% growth in the UK: While we noted above that weather
was a slight help in the UK, we also continue to expect the marketing costs
as a % of sales to fall (we now look for +430/+350bps margin improvement
in the UK in 15E/16E vs +380/+310bps previously). In the UK, greater than 74% of
Q3 orders were via a mobile device (+5ppts vs H1 15), greater than 41% via the app. Q3 group order volumes grew +64%/+48% on a reported/LFL basis,
including +50% growth in the UK: While we noted above that weather
was a slight help in the UK, we also continue to expect the marketing costs
as a % of sales to fall (we now look for +430/+350bps margin improvement
in the UK in 15E/16E vs +380/+310bps previously). In the UK, greater than 74% of
Q3 orders were via a mobile device (+5ppts vs H1 15), greater than 41% via the app.

BE

 Guidance increased: Mgmt are now guiding to slightly above £240m
group revenues in 15E (vs c£230m last guided in August), while they expect
EBITDA to remain on track and in line with current expectations (we note
that the company has clearly communicated that it will reinvest to drive
growth in areas such as marketing and tech; we expect the reinvestment to
be mostly outside the UK in countries such as France, Canada, Spain, Italy).
 We upgrade our numbers; in the last 18 months we have cumulatively
upgraded 2016E UK revenues/EBITDA by +36%+43%, all on an
underlying basis and driven by higher than expected order volumes and
without any potential benefit yet of an increase in commission rates (we
model the first rise in 2018E, which may be conservative). We increase our
UK order vols by +3%+3% in 15E/16E and group vols +3%+5%, our
group revs rise by +4%+4% in 15/16, and U/lying EBITDA by +2%/+2%.

BE

Or, shorter, here's MOST.

11:31 am
BE

The company already raised
revenue guidance in H1 from greater than £212m (proforma for Australia) to £230m in
H1 whilst leaving EBITDA guidance unchanged, and it repeats this quarter. The
company says that it is driving growth through increased investment in
improving the customer experience, bringing greater choice and driving the
shift to mobile. Consensus has EBITDA at £55m. We note that with the shares
having had a strong run into results this might disappoint.
The shares are trading on 34x 2016 and 22x 2017 EV/EBITDA. The
company continues to deliver strong numbers, but the share price leaves no
room for error so we remain on the sidelines.

PM

What are the barriers to entry here? Do they exist at all? It's a trash take away app. In the US there are scores of these I think.

PM

Just Eat going to buy everything launched as a competitor?

11:33 am
BE

The barrier to entry is the wall of money Just Eat and Rocket are placing between them and everyone else to build what they believe will become a defacto monopoly

BE

BE

11:34 am

BE

BE

FY slightly ahead, but Primark isn't

BE

PM

(erlkin -- is it a witch hunt? I'd say one or two companies just been rumbled as spivs.)

11:53 am
BE

Charlie Mills at Credit Suisse rattles through the bullet points.

BE

■ Full year profit and earnings are respectively 2% and 3% ahead of our
forecasts (EPS 102p v 98.7p estimate) – though we leave our 2015/16
forecasts unchanged.
■ Having had a fairly detailed year end trading the shape of the numbers was
much as expected. Sugar and Food were a bit better, Primark as indicated.
■ The Chairman's outlook statement reiterates the comments made in
September concerning on-going FX pressures for 2015/16, and states that
EPS are expected to see a "modest decline" as a result. This is consistent
with our forecasts (we have EPS down 4% from the reported 2015 headline),
so no change to estimates.
■ Primark will always grab the headlines, but we already had seen a strong
finish to the year (+4% like-for-like in Q4). For the new year the Q1
comparatives are soft, and cannibalization impact from Germany is easing.
H1 margins we still expect to be down 200bps ($ costs, £,€ revenues), but
the statement suggests H2 pressures are expected to be a bit less.
■ The group continues to see very high sales densities from new stores, and
re-confirms a 1.5m sq ft (13%) additional space in 2015/16.
■ Though Sugar (and Food to a lesser extent) was better than we thought we
see no reason to change the broad shape of our new year forecasts.

BE

And Barclays with the conference call notes.

11:53 am
BE

Although ABF’s FY16 guidance is of a “modest decline” in FY EPS in FY16, we found the tone of the analyst meeting to be confident. As such, underlying trends at Primark seem encouraging into FY16, and management highlighted a number of costs initiatives taken across businesses (sugar, ingredients) as well as examples of mix-driven margin improvement across the group (tea premiumisation in Grocery, enzymes business in Agriculture). In our view, this suggests that ex currencies, which will particularly impact Retail and Sugar in FY16, and with commodity deflation normalizing, a sound basis for future profit growth is being put in place.

BE

Strong Europe ex. NL and Germany. Germany and the Netherlands bore the bulk of space expansion in FY15 (see table below), and newly opened stores cannibalized like-for-like sales growth at existing stores. Excluding Germany and the Netherlands, however, like for like in FY15 reached 4% (vs. the 1% lfl reported). With the indication that new store cannibalization would be a lesser drag into FY16, and Q4 ending on a strong note (5e% lfl), this provides a supportive outlook on Primark’s organic sales growth.

We also noted management’s indication that the new Madrid Store in Gran Via is not actually impacting the other 6 existing store in the capital (located in the outskirt of the city), evidence, they believe, that Primark is attracting new customers. Management also stressed that FY16 expansion would be focused on France, the UK and Italy, and we noted that Lyon, opened last week, had the strongest opening seen so far in the network, suggesting, in our view, that excitement around the franchise is intact.

BE

Too early to draw conclusions, but Boston is trading well: With only 8 weeks of trading, and while early trends are encouraging (“the store is trading well”), management was reluctant to add any more colour on US prospects, with more comments to be expected at the H1, or FY16. So far, fashion trends are selling well, with good sales of outerwear despite warm weather at the time of the opening. Management believes that Primark’s pricing stands out on the US market, and 7 more stores are due to open in the US in FY16.

Margin mostly reflecting adverse currencies: With so far no change in markdown policy expected in FY16 vs. FY15, the company expects currencies (i.e. higher dollar sourced garments) to have the greatest impact on margin compression next year. Investments in new warehouse facilities will be an additional drag, although to a lesser extent, and the CFO pointed at a -150bps decline in Primark’s FY margin, with a greater decline in the H1, to be expected. Management stressed that Primark has not raised prices and that at this stage, they have not seen signs of price increases in any European markets.

11:54 am
BE

Management retained a cautious view on world sugar prices, as despite a recent uptick in prices driven by drought in India, global stocks remain high. However, in Europe, management showed confidence the business could be durably profitable assuming sugar prices of EUR450/tone, stressing that beet costs (c20% in both FY16 and FY17) and costs savings were very positive drivers behind profits growth.

The contracting period is almost over in Europe, and management pointed at improvement in selling prices from EUR419/tonne last reported by the European Commission as of August. However this year, currencies (pound costs base, EUR-denominated selling prices) and lower fixed costs absorption (British sugar production is expected down 30%, to 1m tonne sugar, from 1.45m last year) will be two key headwinds on profits this year.

BE

Can't be easy being CEO of AB Foods, having to know both about European sugar legislation and American fast fashion trends.

PM

I saw George Weston speak a little while back

PM

BE

BE
